Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Using Computer Vision to Measure Neighborhood Variables Affecting Health

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will develop an automated method, using advances in computer science, to observe and record systematically the physical conditions of neighborhood environments at a large-scale. Neighborhood environments play a significant role in shaping the health of individuals and communities, consequently contributing to inequality in the U.S. Past research suggests that the presence of physical disorder, poorly maintained properties, and vacant lots in neighborhoods can negatively affect physical and mental health, attract more crime and disorder, and lead to neighborhood disinvestment. The measures resulting from this study will facilitate examination of these processes and provide a powerful resource for the scientific research community. They will be more broadly beneficial as well by allowing policymakers, practitioners, and the public to track neighborhood progress and target improvements.

The project takes advantage of Google Street View imagery--the largest publicly available longitudinal dataset of visual appearance of street blocks--and will use Amazon's Mechanical Turk--a crowdsourcing platform--and existing field survey data to identify indicators of physical disorder and maintenance, such as trash and blighted buildings, on a sample of street segments across three distinct cities: Boston, Detroit, and Los Angeles. These data will be used to train an algorithm that draws on recent advances in machine learning and computer vision. Reliability and validity of the method for identifying characteristics and measures will be tested throughout each step of the process. The resulting longitudinal measures of the physical conditions of neighborhoods will be linked to longitudinal health surveys conducted in each of the three cities to analyze the relationship between physical neighborhood conditions and health. In addition, the new measures will be released as a publicly available database of longitudinal measures of physical neighborhood conditions across multiple cities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project developed an automated method to systematically observe and record the physical conditions of neighborhood environments at a large-scale. Neighborhood environments play a significant role in shaping the health of individuals and communities, consequently contributing to inequality in the U.S. Past research suggests that the presence of physical disorder, poorly maintained properties, and vacant lots in neighborhoods can negatively affect physical and mental health, attract more crime and disorder, and lead to neighborhood disinvestment. Few studies, however, examine this process because collecting data on the physical conditions of neighborhoods, especially across neighborhoods and cities and over time, requires extensive time and labor costs. The project drew from street view imagery, crowdsourcing, and deep machine learning and assessed the extent to which indicators of physical disorder of varying complexity can be identified across three physically distinct cities—Boston, Detroit, and Los Angeles—in  images ranging from 2007 to 2018 and the extent to which the method can be applied to other cities.

The pipeline developed in this project predicts the presence of trash in images with relatively high accuracy (86% average across the three cities), while the accuracy of predictions for the level of trash across three levels was lower (78% average across the three cities). Predictions for the presence of trash have high agreement with trained student raters (83.1% agreement). Disagreement among trained student raters as well as between trained student raters, predictions using machine learning, and crowdsourced data is primarily due to the inability to distinguish between trash and small objects, such as leaves and street markings, and this is especially difficult when shadows are present. Across blocks, census block groups, and census tracts, the presence of trash is spatially clustered such that images within units strongly resemble each other in terms of the presence of trash. The prevalence of trash in neighborhoods has different relationships with demographic and housing characteristics across different cities. Finally, training the model on three physically distinct cities predicted the presence of trash relatively well in Philadelphia, PA and Austin, TX. Predictions had high agreement with trained student raters (85.0% agreement in both cities), suggesting that scaling this method to other cities is promising.

 

The resulting data is the first of its kind: a longitudinal dataset of the visible physical conditions of neighborhoods across multiple cities. Measures of the physical conditions of neighborhoods at a large-scale and over time across multiple cities can enhance the study of contributors to inequality in the US. These data enable researchers to study one of the major posited pathways through which neighborhoods affect individual- and community health and well-being and to measure the physical changes of neighborhood environments at a fine-grained temporal and spatial scale. This research can also offer a pipeline for other social scientists to use for scaling labeled data to handle large datasets. For example, the pipeline can be developed further to identify building conditions and maintenance levels of exterior frontage areas and to expand predictions to other cities for various spatial aggregations. These data can be linked to other data sources, such as longitudinal health surveys, crime data, demographic data, and housing price data to analyze the relationships between physical neighborhood conditions and individual and community well-being. This interdisciplinary project provided research opportunities for several undergraduate and graduate students in various fields at Stanford University, including Computer Science, Sociology, Psychology, Management Science and Engineering, and Symbolic Systems, who were nearly all students of color, underrepresented minorities, and/or women.

 


Last Modified: 09/08/2020
Modified by: Jackelyn Hwang
